report_title: Cell Site Operation and Leasing in the US
executive_summary: In the rapidly evolving landscape of cell site operation and leasing, industry operators have found themselves at a pivotal crossroads. The aftermath of the pandemic has reshaped not just societal norms but the very backbone of telecommunications infrastructure, enabling revenue to expand at a CAGR of 0.2% beyond inflation to $48.0 billion in 2024. More than ever, low-income residential areas are becoming focal points for intense bandwidth consumption, weakening the industry's focus on nonresidential zones. This shift demands an agile response, propelling operators to fortify their infrastructure in urban and rural communities to meet the growing appetite for connectivity by major wireless operators.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THE PANDEMIC PROMPTED A PIVOT TO RESIDENTIAL CELL USAGE AS OFFICES AND SHOPS DIALED DOWN
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As the pandemic swept the US, changes in work and lifestyle patterns spurred a marked shift in cell plans and internet usage. The cell site lessors observed a surge in demand for residential bandwidth as remote work and online schooling became the norm. This trend challenged the industry's pre-pandemic focus on nonresidential areas, prompting a strategic pivot towards enhancing capacity and coverage in residential zones.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: 5G DRIVES DENSE DEPLOYMENT OF SMALL CELLS IN CONCRETE JUNGLES
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The rollout of 5G technology, particularly with its focus on millimeter wave (mmWave) frequencies, has fundamentally altered the urban landscape for the Cell Site Operation and Leasing industry. mmWave frequencies offer unprecedented data speeds but at the cost of reduced penetration power through obstacles like buildings and trees. To mitigate this, the industry has intensified the deployment of small cells—compact, short-range transmission systems—across urban areas.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: ROOFTOP REAL ESTATE PRICES SKYROCKET, PUSHING MOBILE CARRIERS TOWARD INVENTIVE URBAN SOLUTIONS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the cost of securing rooftop locations for cell sites in metropolitan areas spirals upward, cell site lessors will increasingly see mobile carriers pivot towards more cost-effective, innovative solutions that bypass the need for towers. Micro-cell networks, utilizing small, strategically placed nodes often in collaboration with public infrastructure, will become the go-to choice.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: SATELLITES HANG OVER THE FATE OF RURAL CELL SITES
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The burgeoning development of direct-to-satellite communication technologies threatens to undercut the conventional cell site model, especially in sparsely populated areas. With tech giants launching constellations of low-earth orbit (LEO) satellites, individuals in remote locations might soon bypass ground-based cell networks altogether. This poses a significant risk to operators of rural cell sites, who could see their roles and relevancies eroded over time.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE FURTHER ADVANCEMENT IN TECHNOLOGY AND CONSUMER EXPECTATIONS WILL PUSH FOR GREATER INNOVATION
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The widespread adoption of e-SIM technology is set to revolutionize carrier-customer dynamics, making the process of switching service providers nearly seamless. OpenSignal reports predict a fivefold increase in carrier swapping compared to traditional SIM card use. For Cell Site Operation and Leasing companies that primarily cater to single carriers, this could spell increased volatility as customer loyalties fluctuate more rapidly.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry own, operate, lease and manage wireless communication towers and other infrastructure. This industry owns the real estate and maintains the structure, but does not operate the radio transceivers on the tower.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers: Number of mobile internet connections
threats: Low Outlier Growth: Value of private nonresidential construction

key_trends: Providing competitive market prices enhances internal competition.
Operators that offer more-favorable leasing terms create an incentive, particularly for smaller cellular carriers, to sign a lease agreement.

Advancement of Wi-Fi technology influences external competition. As more locations adopt Wi-Fi connectivity, whether at home or in a corporate setting, it dampens demand for traditional cellular communications.

For the average consumer, a smartphone is the only computer they own. People use smartphones to consume art, browse social media, administer their finances and shop online. All these use cases require fast and reliable data networks that cell site operators must design and maintain.

The allure of rooftop real estate in densely populated areas is giving way to micro-cell networks, which promise carriers cost-effective urban coverage through a mosaic of small, unobtrusive nodes. As direct-to-satellite communication looms as a formidable disruptor, rural cell site operators brace for an existential shift.

High cost of operations limits growth opportunities. Even as established companies such as Crown Castle International Corp. maintain existing cell sites, the high cost of maintaining access and functionality limits opportunities for broader market expansion.

Robust growth in competition dampens expansion opportunities. As smaller mobile network carriers continue to gain interest in cell sites, many smaller operators will be incentivized to enter the marketplace.
Cell site operations has greatly benefited from the growing prevalence of mobile internet connections and broadband

market_segmentation.segment_description: Navigating through a densely populated market, AT&T exhibits agility by adopting innovative tower sharing initiatives, like its partnership with Crown Castle. This forward-thinking approach suggests an evolution towards a synergistic ecosystem where collaboration trumps singular conquest. As AT&T faces the magnifying glass of scrutiny with sporadic tower outages hinting at possible sabotage, resilience becomes key in safeguarding infrastructure integrity— a prime concern for both providers and lessees. Compelled by antitrust watchdogs to potentially shed some of their tower holdings, AT&T is thrust onto the highwire act of balancing expansionist ambitions with the legislative demands for an equitable marketplace. In light of these pressures, AT&T's tower strategies may set powerful precedents in an industry grappling with rapid technological transformation and complex regulatory landscapes.

Verizon casts a prominent shadow in the dynamic landscape of cell tower leasing, standing out for directly owning more towers than its competitors instead of leasing them. They are also generally understood to have superior coverage across the US than their competitors. The telecom heavyweight's strategic expansion into underrepresented rural territories by partnering with tower leasing companies underscored a push towards ubiquitous 5G connectivity. Verizon's proactive stance comes with many complexities: its recent divestment of surplus towers in a billion-dollar leaseback transaction to American Tower offers an intelligent play to liquidate assets while preserving network access, indicating savvy capital management.

In the wake of T-Mobile's merger with Sprint, redundancy in towers and contracts has morphed into a strategic conundrum, prompting divesture to streamline operations. Locking in a nationwide deal with American Tower Corporation signifies T-Mobile's commitment to long-term infrastructure solidity and perhaps hints at potential cost efficiencies down the line. Recent conversations with Dish Network also illustrate T-Mobile's willingness to negotiate shared swathes of the network sky, suggesting that cooperative paradigms might be the new competitive edge - shared infrastructure could redefine how carriers coexist and flourish.

The MVNO and non-cellular network sphere is entering a bold era, seeking autonomy as they make direct overtures to tower lessors to widen coverage vistas beyond the confines of significant carrier partnerships. MVNO advocates champion broader tower access from carriers as a clarion call for democratized networks parading enhanced competitive rates and consumer choice. Google Fi's satellite-aided rural leap exemplifies the relentless pursuit of connectivity transcendence, drawing upon celestial networks to deliver terrestrial service. Meanwhile, private LTE networks are becoming a thing since a burgeoning appetite among enterprises has erected fresh challenges for traditional carriers. With smartphone usage steadily growing following COVID-19 and less-expensive wireless plans being offered, operators have a lucrative market niche for leasing cell sites.

products_and_services.product_description: This product segment generates revenue from the leasing of wireless communication towers, also known as cell sites.
This product segment generates revenue from provision of wireless tower inspection services.
This product segment generates revenue from the sales of tower installation and support services.

Professional, Scientific and Technical Services in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The telecommunications services sector, especially wireless telecommunications carriers, comprises a significant market for industry operators. Wireless telecommunications providers outsource tower and other infrastructure operation services to industry operators. When telecommunications service providers experience strong growth, they also invest more in infrastructure projects. Demand from wireless telecommunications carriers is anticipated to increase.

business_locations.location_description: Urban environments, particularly high-density areas, are prime stages for the rollout of 5G millimeter-wave (mmWave) technology, offering unparalleled speeds and capacity. However, deploying this next-gen tech comes with its unique set of challenges. As a result of mmWave's shorter range and inability to penetrate buildings effectively, operators need a higher number of cell sites, often creatively disguised to blend with the urban landscape - think cell towers masquerading as streetlights or building elements. Securing rights to place equipment on buildings or public right-of-ways in bustling cities like New York or San Francisco demands rigorous negotiations and regulatory navigation, making the deployment a logistical tightrope walk.

In suburban sprawls, the landscape shifts. Here, the focus is on deploying standard 5G technology, which strikes a balance between speed and coverage range. The suburbs present a balanced landscape for cell site deployment, catering well to the medium density of these areas. The essential advantage for cell site lessors in the suburbs lies in the relative ease of installing new infrastructure compared to the cramped and contested urban spaces. However, the challenge here pivots to ensuring comprehensive coverage that seamlessly bridges the gap between dense urban centers and sparse rural locales, prompting a strategic placement of cell sites that maximizes coverage while minimizing costs.

Amid the 5G rollout, rural areas continue relying on robust 4G LTE networks. In these low-density environments, the focus for operators is on maintaining and upgrading existing towers to ensure uninterrupted service. The expansive geography and dispersed demographic mean operators often opt for longer-range single towers rather than the dense network of sites needed for 5G. While this approach is cost-effective concerning infrastructure, it presents challenges in delivering higher data speeds and connectivity that urban and suburban users are beginning to take for granted, highlighting the digital divide still prevalent in many parts of the country.

Moving indoors, the narrative changes significantly. In densely utilized indoor spaces like subways, shopping malls, and large office buildings, providing reliable cell service becomes a puzzle. Here, picocells come into play, small cellular base stations designed to operate in compact areas where traditional signal penetration falls short. Deploying these units allows operators to offer high-capacity coverage tailored to the specific needs of these environments, ensuring users stay connected even deep within buildings.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Cell site operators must adhere to a variety of regulatory constraints at the federal level from the FCC. These regulations focus on ensuring cell site towers are adequately constructed and have proper lighting systems to avert any threat to oncoming air traffic. The FCC also requires certain licenses to ensure compliance with additional air safety standards via the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) if a tower is located near an airport.

Operators must also adhere to a variety of zoning and permitting requirements among local governments. If an operator wants to construct a new cell site, they must gain zoning approval on the land they plan to use and have to adhere to local ordinances focused on preserving community safety and environmental compliance.

Passed in 1996, the US Telecommunications Act provided updated framework on state and local zoning guidelines while also encouraging new development of communications infrastructure. Most of the law's target was focused on siting regulations of smaller cell sites, which is particularly impactful in smaller cities and suburbs. The law gave more leverage to the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) in fostering new developments and meeting regulatory guidelines.

Since cell site operators are involved in the construction and maintenance of cell sites, they must also adhere to a variety of environmental guidelines at the federal and local levels. These guidelines set limits to ensure operators meet the required threshold for air and water quality, while also respecting local wildlife in the region. This is particularly important for cell sites built in more rural areas.

barriers_points.barrier_description: There are significant legal barriers for new operators. Cell site operators must adhere to a variety of state and local regulations focused on environmental compliance and telecommunication laws.

Operators face notable start-up costs when procuring a cell site. They must acquire the necessary land to construct a cell site, hire a noteworthy number of qualified employees for construction and maintenance of cell sites.

There is limited differentiation across the product stream. Operators primarily procure revenue via wireless communication tower leases to a variety of wireless carriers, with limited room for differentiation for new operators.

Although some capital is required, operators face significantly higher labor intensity. Cell sites require qualified staff to ensure they are adequately built, function properly and maintain steady performance levels.

basis_points.basis_description: Providing competitive market prices enhances internal competition.
Operators that offer more-favorable leasing terms create an incentive, particularly for smaller cellular carriers, to sign a lease agreement.

Advancement of Wi-Fi technology influences external competition. As more locations adopt Wi-Fi connectivity, whether at home or in a corporate setting, it dampens demand for traditional cellular communications.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The prevalence of smaller cell site providers across the United States makes it difficult for existing operators to capture a larger share of the market. Since cell sites are primarily localized near highly populated areas, it provides opportunities for smaller operators to acquire a larger number of cell sites.

Existing operators face significant operational costs, ranging from high wages for their employees, to compliance costs toward a variety of regulations. This limits opportunities for growth and encourages capturing a specific market niche within its area of operations.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Costs for Land Increase as All the Best Cell Sites are Already Taken
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Land purchases are critical as the location of a cell tower directly impacts its effectiveness and coverage area. Strategic land acquisition is crucial for expanding network coverage or filling in coverage gaps. Recent years have seen a rising trend in the costs associated with these purchases, given the scarcity of prime locations as the best cell sites are already taken.

Companies are exploring lease agreements or partnerships with landowners instead of outright purchases to manage these costs. Investments in newer, more efficient technologies requiring less physical space can lower initial purchase costs.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Depreciation of a Tower Can Be Minimized by Continuous Upkeep
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Depreciation is a significant cost given the rapid technological advancements and the subsequent necessity for upgrades. Companies constantly seek to extend their assets' lifecycle through maintenance and upgrades to manage these costs effectively.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Cell Tower Operators Turn to Alternative Energy and Batteries to Help Carriers Maintain Reliable Service
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Utility costs can vary widely depending on the exact location, availability of utility infrastructure and power of the antennas. Companies have been exploring using renewable energy sources, such as solar panels and batteries, to power some of the tower's operations to reduce utility costs and improve sustainability.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Although some capital is required, operators face significantly higher labor intensity. Cell sites require qualified staff to ensure they are adequately built, function properly and maintain steady performance levels.

volatility_points.volatility_title: BURGEONING DEMAND FOR HIGH-SPEED INTERNET CONNECTIVITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: The relentless march of technology, especially the transition from 4G to 5G networks, has introduced a complex layer of volatility as cell site operators scramble to upgrade infrastructure while balancing declining revenues from older technologies.

volatility_points.volatility_title: GOVERNMENT INVESTMENT AND REGULATION IN TELECOMMUNICATIONS EQUIPMENT
volatility_points.volatility_description: Fluctuations in the regulatory environment, including changes in zoning laws and spectrum allocations, have injected an element of unpredictability into the industry's revenue patterns, mandating nimble strategic adjustments.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Acceleration of 5G technology adoption advances cell site operations
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: With 5G adoption spiking in recent years and the broader development of mobile technology, cell site operators have benefited from advancements in wireless device technology via 5G upgrades.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Advancement in automated technology improves efficiency of cell site construction
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: As operators continue to improve their construction efficiency, they could use automated technology, such as drones and 3D imaging, to assist in cell site construction.

FAQs.question: Does your company primarily work with residential or nonresidential construction markets?
FAQs.answer: Companies primarily work with nonresidential construction markets.

FAQs.question: Does your company work to anticipate changes in sales based on current market performance?
FAQs.answer: Companies expect sales to fluctuate based on the demand for wireless communication services.

FAQs.question: Have the rising prices of key infrastructure inputs significantly affected profit margins in recent years?
FAQs.answer: Rising prices of steel and other key inputs have negatively affected average profitability.

FAQs.question: What is the size of your staff? How does that compare to your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Staff sizes range between 20 and 50 workers typically per establishment.

FAQs.question: How much does your company invest in new equipment annually?
FAQs.answer: Investment in new technology is important to keep up with changing market demands.

FAQs.question: In light of increasing wage costs, has your company considered using new technologies to increase productivity or reduce total employment?
FAQs.answer: Skilled labor is a necessity in this industry to effectively operate and maintain cell sites.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted your company's profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Regulatory expenses have been quite high as cellular service companies buy up freed spectrum directly from the FCC to expand their cellular capabilities.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met on and off the cell site?
FAQs.answer: Companies tend to follow federal and state guidelines to make sure health and safety requirements are met.

FAQs.question: What ongoing financing challenges does your company face?
FAQs.answer: One of the biggest financing challenges for companies is purchase costs, which can account for more than one-third of revenue in a year.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare with your competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Company profit margin is typically low because of the large infrastructure investment required to begin earning profit.

FAQs.question: How do you make sure your prices are attractive to customers? How effective is your company at competing on tender?
FAQs.answer: Contracts are often open to bidding, and industry participants must have the capability to provide competitive tender while remaining profitable.

FAQs.question: Do you have a strong reputation among customers? Are you known for your reliability and performance?
FAQs.answer: Establishing a reputation for quality workmanship, technical capabilities, and timeliness is essential for securing contracts and referrals.
